												Like strategy games, but don't want to deal with all the complex mechanisms present in 4X games or battle non-stop "Zerg rushes" in RTS?  If so, you might actually like this game.  It's basically the classic game RISK, but the "Factions" version involves playing one of five different groups: humans, robots, cats, yetis and the undead.  The only differences are visual (i.e. no faction-based special attacks or anything), but it adds a lively -- and often quite amusing -- flourish to what some consider a boring game.  The classic version is available, as well.The single player campaign is rather short, although the AI is cheap.  You can beat it eventually, but doing so relies more on luck than anything else.  Multiplayer is online or hot-seat.  All in all, it's an inexpensive strategy game that's easy to learn and visually more entertaining and accessible for those not normally inclined toward this genre.

TL;DRNeat for anyone who likes a simplified RISK to play with friends online, and doesn't want to wait an hour for decisions to be made. ProsGraphicsSimpleConsDrag and Click doesn't always select properlyRNG seems stupid at times Gameplay I've been meaning to learn RISK for a while. It was always one of those games that I saw and heard a lot about, but never quite got around to the stage of persuading people to sit around a table and play it. With RISK: Factions on steam, this problem is eliminated. If you have no clue whatsoever on how to play the game, this will give you a nice crash course, though the rules it offers with the Factions element are a lot more simplified than the normal rules. They also make the gameplay a lot faster. It can be fiddly working with the faster drag and release methods to speed up troop fights. You can either watch fights happen, including each painstaking dice roll, or just speed through them. Sometimes it doesn't always work when selecting and choosing – and with smaller territories they can be hard to highlight. I've had quite a few incidents where I wanted to invade a specific territory, and it took me 20 or so tries before the area finally got highlighted.The main campaign mode is designed basically to give you the rules on this version of the game, and introduce you to five “leaders” who each have their quirks. You also get the option to have the classic RISK map without the added faction goodies, a classic RISK map with them thrown in, and a faster win method, or utilising maps that showed throughout the campaign, with their specific objectives. You can control one of five leaders: McGutterpants, Generalissmo Meow, His Excellency, Gary, Commandant SixFour, or Colonal Stiffenberg, You can either take objectives on the map for extra bonuses within game, such as an enemy city or capital, or achieve something such as taking over 5 territories in one turn -- to gain advantages over the rest. I can guarantee RNG will annoy you a lot. It can be depressing to see your 10 troops fail to take over an country with only 2 troops defending. Such is the way of the RNG Gods.The graphics are cartoonish and comical in nature. The faction leaders are funny, with their own animations and expressions for when they attack, lose land, and gain land. The maps themselves are easy to follow, and quite bright. The music is alright, there's nothing I would find outstanding about it – same with the voice acting tailored to the faction leaders.There's nothing particularly special about this game, but if you want to play RISK, learn the rules, and be able to play with friends online, then this is definitely worth some of your hours.Want moar? 												This is such a close toss up. I really love the original RISK game but this version just has one too many problems.It won't show you the die rolls, once ONE unit attacks a country you HAVE to keep attacking until one of the countries loses all of its men, there's no way to stop. No wearing the enemy down slowly. You have to go all in. But you don't actually know who's winning becausue you can't see the dice.The dice rolls themselves are probably hidden because they're not very realistic. 1 unit will defend of 25 units a turn, every turn, indefinitely.If you play with Computer Players it doesn't count up how many units they SHOULD receive at the beginning of the turn but instead just gives them insane numbers of units without explanation, ie. He has 1 country, 0 capitals, 0 cities, so he receives 35 units. Then he also turned in 2 stars so he receives another 35 units.Guy that literally has one country left was just given 70 units and wins the game in a single turn.This ONLY happens to the AI players. It actually counts out the units given to the human players, and it doesn't give them unfair help.All that being said multiplayer online is so buggy you can actually only play 1 out of every 5 games through. Most of the time it will stop working, ie. You can no longer click or move the mouse, someone's turn is permanently skipped, the game kicks a human player for no reason and replaces it with an AI mid-game without permission,But it is kinda fun the one out of ten times it works. Lots of different levels and you don't need to play with the silly cartoon characters if you don't like them, but personally I like them.

												The idea is fantastic.  I like all the extra stuff, the various 'things' that you can capture to change the way the game plays.  The writing is humorous.  It's Risk plus a bit more.And then the problems.  The campaign was...an introduction to the various factions.  That's it.  You didn't get to pick sides.  You simply got to play as the new faction.  But what's different about each faction?  The animations and the color!  That's it.  It's RISK so I really don't ask for the factions to have different powers.  But the animations.  They're cute, they're funny, I think they're well done...until you've witnessed them for the 100th time.  You can make the dice go faster...by giving up the dice all together and committing fully to the attack.  Tired of the slow animations that were fun and cute for the first couple hours?  Well, you can speed up the animation where the computer takes over territories (that's the ONLY animation that speeds up when you hit fast forward).  Tired of that same message that says "cities help your ability to draft new soldiers"?  Too bad.  The game will remind you EVERY TIME YOU TAKE A TERRITORY WITH A CITY, duh, you're obviously too dumb to've got it the first 50 times it told you.  ^_^So I got tired of the aniimations.  I'll play Classic RIsk!  I thought.  How could they screw that up?  That's been done before.  All the rules and the standard variat...oh, there are no variations... fine.  Aaaaaaaand then I get gang♥♥♥♥♥♥♥  I understand.  I get it.  I don't win Risk all the time.  But when I lose, because one of the AIs turns in three sets of cards, three turns in a row, and then...I'm still alive...I have a set...it's the draft phase but I CAN'T TURN IN THE SET because the game lagged (single player) and I clicked on the card menu, which closed the card menu...but then I open it back up and can't turn it in?  ♥♥♥♥ you Risk Factions.  ♥♥♥♥ you.Oh, and the actual game controller controls are not properly reflected on the screen.  Really?  The developer can't even get the controls to be properly reflected on the screen?So to summarize:  This game is like that pretty guy or girl that you've just scored a date with.  They're fun, they're fantastic, they seem to be everything you want.  That little thing they do that annoys you, that's no big deal--until you discover that there are a lot of those "little things that annoy you"  I do think it's almost worth the $10 I paid for it.  I certainly got two or three good hours of enjoyment out of it--but I can't recommend it.  It seems like a solid game until you get under the hood and check it out.
